-The lead female (Fino Bloodstone) is almost less than 1 Dimensional, she's completely helpless, clumsy, air-headed, and just a plain stereotype.

-It borders on being a harem, with at least 3-4 love interests for the MC.



Sound 5/10:

Typically, if the opening is a cutesy pop song sung by a group of girls in squeaky high voices, it's a clear sign that you're watching a bad anime.


Art: 7/10:

The visuals are what you'd expect from something without a huge budget that's designed to bump interest and sales in the other merchandise of the series like Figurines, Manga, Costumes, etc.


Characters 5/10:

Nearly every one of them is one dimensional, with seldom to overcome other than Fino getting used to the human world.


Enjoyment 6/10:

It's light hearted, and that's good if you've just gone through an anime that has a serious moment that weighs pretty heavily on your heart, like Episode 16 of Robotics;Notes (that one still effects me).



So yeah, in the end it wasn't anything unique, and that's how I rate a lot of anime. It didn't make me think, it wasn't awesome, it wasn't actually romantic, there was no mystery, nothing major to overcome, nothing that we didn't see coming, and barely a plot twist.


All it was really focusing on was MOE and Fanservice. You can skip it and miss out on nothing.

If you like boobs jiggling all over the place, harems, and no story, this was MADE for you. I figured that it would be something like 'Hataraku Maou-Sama!', it wasn't. It was like they took that already sub-par anime, blended it, then skimmed all of the fluffy goodness that made it it, then dumped the rest in a bucket labeled 'bad anime'. I have got to say, I don't remember much from this anime (since I watched it quite a while back), but I don't remember crap about the main character. I feel like in order to have a good show, the main character hasgot to be at least memorable. I do remember the love interest however: she had a good design and was a well rounded character; but, those last few episodes, they just pissed me off. Why? Why the heck did they decide part-way through that it actually needed a story. The magic system already sucked, the MC sucked, the gross CG sucked: it could of at least been reserved as a stupid, but funny slice-of-life. But no, they just had to try to put a story on this thing. It's like trying to clothe Beelzebub, it's just not going to work. All in all, it deserved a 3, more like a high 2. Ugh, that espionage episode, I'm going to go throw up now...

Yuushibu is an Ecchi/Comedy anime with some minor action and romance type aspects. While the premise is similar to The Devil is a Part Timer, the focus of the shows are not.
The story is simple. Raul Chaser is working at a magic items store (instead of electricity things are run by magic) but his real dream is to be a hero. However, because the demon lord was defeated there is no need for them anymore. One day a "guy" walks into the store and applies... this "guy" happens to be the demon lords kid. Okay, the "guy" is really a girl named Fino, the demonlords daughter.


One thing this anime does very well is executing the premise. Each episode the characters (mostly Fino) learns something about her job or life outside the demon realm in general. At the same time... it kind of reflects like real life situations and such. It even had this whole thing about the big department store out pricing the small local shops by literally working small demons to death. I want to say that I really like the world they built in the anime. I thought using normal household appliances and having them powered by magic in this fantasy world was a great idea.


Yes a big aspect of the show is fan-service and honestly in the first episode it's not that well placed. However, I don't think people should mind that much after that episode. There is a lot of fan-service but eventually it's almost completely becomes integrated into the story/situations rather than just being there for the sake of having it (okay I totally realize the situations are set up for fan service but come on)


The main pair in Raul and Fino make a great team. Fino starts out very naive (and mainly stays that way) but she does learn concepts at a regular basis. Not only this but she actually has actual insight into some concepts which automatically makes her smarter than 99% of anime females. While Raul's character and the way he progresses is rather predictable but he changes gradually as Fino learns. He learns through teaching and experience and not through endless exposition.


If I had a complaint is that the show is too straight forward and cliche. It does everything it sets out to do very well, has likeable characters that get development over the entirety of the series, and does not faulter on sound or animation. However, the ending is essentially saving the day because of the power of LOVE and saving a floating pair of chesticles.

I Couldn't Become a Hero, So I Reluctantly Decided to Get a Job
 Ecchi ecchi fun.
 I Couldn't Become a Hero is a pretty fun show about a guy who, as the title says, who couldn't become a hero. He works in a magic item store, reluctantly of course, when a new girl appears with a resume in hand and wants to work at the same store. The new girl, named Fino, has a really interesting background, so interesting that it can change the course of the world!
 The story, for the most part is a very fun slice of life about working in aretail store when competition emerges, forcing everyone to work harder to make the store more known and popular. It's not until the last 3-4 episodes where a plot appears from quite literally no where and changes the direction of the anime.


 The girls, Fino, Elsa, Airi, Nova, Saera, Lore and Lamdimia are all really insanely cute and pretty. The art style, like many harems and anime that want to accentuate cuteness, use red blemish marks on the skin, typically around the thighs, breasts, cheeks, elbows shoulders, things of that nature; it works really well and it make all the girls so much cuter! ! !


 Fino, the main girl of the anime, is a totally adorable demon with a bright passion for wanting to succeed and to become something with her life; she's also has an incredibly infectious cheerful and peppy personality, making her a lot of fun to watch and care for. Raul, our main guy for I Could Become a Hero, is like most MC's in a harem based situation; he gets flustered when breasts are near him, he loses composure when a girl clings to him, but aside from that, he can be a cool guy, he'd obviously be a lot better if he made some magic happen.


 There are some minor characters that become a little important during the last 2-3 episodes of the anime, but I don't think I really enjoyed seeing the drastic and entirely different direction the anime went into. I guess in many ways, it makes sense and works, but I'd rather not have seen Fino get manipulated and toyed with.


 The music in I Couldn't Become a Hero, is surprisingly good. The OP and ED are quite amazing and will probably find the artist who did the songs, but the background music was good and so were the ambient based sounds, I didn't really expect that at all.


 Like I mentioned before, the art style is one that accentuates cuteness and is animated in such a way to make sure you notice the bouncing boobies and beautiful girls, a lot of good.


 I Couldn't Become a Hero is really a show for people looking for a lot of ecchi. We have pantsu shots, both the front and the back, we have beautiful bouncing breasts, we have nipples and amazing ass shots. The first couple episodes start off really strong on the fan service aspect too, even having a couple tentacle(hands) scenes that when explode, turn into a white mess....

Is it just me, or do the Japanese love giving their anime over-the-top, overly long, ridiculous titles. I Couldn't Become a Hero, So I Reluctantly Decided to Get a Job is the story about a young man who went to an academy where people trained to defeat the Dark Lord. Unfortunately, the Dark Lord was defeated before he even graduated and the academy went under. Destitute and in need of money, Raul Chaser reluctantly gets a job working for a magic appliance retail store. Months later, another person also begins working there - the Dark Lord's only daughter, Fino Bloodstone. Can't you just smell therecipe for disaster here?


This is one of those anime that I feel is underrated. Sure, it's not the best. In fact, most of it is downright cliched. However, I think this anime understands that it's a cliche and doesn't pretend to be something else. The humor, while seen in every ecchi anime series, is well-done and over-the-top. The ecchi is, well, ecchi. There's not much that can be said there. This is an anime that has plenty of boobs for young men who want fan service to enjoy. While I'm sometimes sketchy about ecchi, this anime is of the ecchi genre, so pandering to fan service actually works here - unlike some of the other anime I have watched.


The animation is okay. Honestly, I've seen better, but I've seen worse as well. This is a middle-tier anime, where the animations aren't terrible, but not amazing to the point where you're thinking, "wow! The animation is so flawless, and the frame rate is amazing!" I will admit, though, that I do like the artwork. It's sort of standard, but it's still nice. The girls, in particular, are well designed. I suppose that's only natural, since this is an ecchi anime. No one's gonna want to watch an anime about boobs and nude scenes if the female's weren't hotter than sin.


Despite this being an ecchi anime where most of the plot is, um, well, PLOT, this does have a somewhat interesting story. It also makes you wonder. What happens to the people who tried to become a hero but, due to unforeseen circumstances, never got the chance? This story deals with a new, intriguing aspect to heroism and Dark Lord slaying that I haven't seen before. Raul Chaser is a man who dreamed of defeating the Dark Lord and becoming a hero, yet now he's stuck working at a retail store because none of the vaunted, Dark Lord slaying abilities he has are useful in anything but, well, Dark Lord slaying. Now he has to deal with the fact that he's essentially wasted several years of his life learning how to become a hero in a world where heroes aren't needed. To make matters more interesting, one of his co-workers happens to be the daughter of the Dark Lord that he wanted to kill, which adds a new dynamic to the story.


Aside from Raul Chaser, Fino Bloodstone, and Ahri All-A, none of the characters are really touched upon. This isn't as bad as it sounds. Like I said. This is an ecchi anime. Literally. It's genre is ecchi. In an anime where the story is merely an excuse to deliver boob scenes to the audience, character development isn't that important. I was honestly surprised that these three actually received the development they had. Raul and Ahri deal with what it means to live in a world where their skills are no longer needed, and Fino is dealing with the fact that she's a demon, the daughter of the Dark Lord, living in a world that she doesn't understand. While the plot never gets very deep or complex, sticking with mostly comedy and slapstick humor, the way these aspects are pulled off is well-done.

Yusibu is a decent ecchi anime that has many fantasy elements. At its core, Yusibu relies on the formula of Beverly Hillbillies and takes a person from a faraway place with different customs and understandings and puts them in a modern setting where hilarity ensues. Make the modern setting a fantasy world where magic equals the technology you see in the real world and have the strange newcomer be the daughter of the demon lord, sprinkle in some ecchi for some added spice and you have yourself a show. That said, Yusibu is not a bad show, and I would even call it a greatshow at the beginning, but it does falter at the end so I must declare it just a good show.


The main characters are Raul Chaser and Fino Bloodstone. Raul Chaser is a man who dreamed of being a hero but that particular career field ended with the death of the demon lord, and Fino Bloodstone is the previously mentioned daughter of the demon lord that wants to live in the human world. Both these characters are employees in magical appliance store with Raul being the senior store employing showing Fino the ropes to her new job. The best part of the anime has to be the interaction between these two. Raul makes a wonderful straight man. He is established as a bad ass early on in the series who has the misfortune of working in retail. He handles himself in a much more reasonable manner than your typical ecchi male lead, though this does wear off as the series goes. Fino has an extremely energetic and optimistic attitude, but that doesn’t really help her at all when it comes to working in retail. I do like how she isn’t depicted as being stupid or clumsy, but as a fish out of water. It is nice to see her slowly get the hang of things as time goes on, but that makes it even more funnier when she makes hilarious mistakes because there still more to learn.


The plot of the anime mainly revolves around the business that Raul and Fino work at, whether that is trying to learn how to interact with customers or tying to think of way to drum up business because a big competitor has moved into town. While the story is not the greatest, it allowed for comedic situations so I never found myself bored while watching it. I was disappointed how the show takes a very simplistic look at economics and the nature of running a business, but it’s really shame on me for expecting insightful discourse on the benefits and dangers of capitalism from an anime that contains a gratuitous amount of bouncing boobs in its OP. The ending was disappointing; there was really little buildup to the climax and there were multiple cases of deus ex machine. It would easily have been a great ended if the series used more foreshadowing and introduced the final antagonists sooner.


There really isn’t anything in Yosibu that makes me believed it will be remembered years from now, but it is worthy for a look now and a quick laugh.

Anyone who says this series is a clone of hataraku maou-sama only read the synopsis then got their fandom pitch forks out. It's a similar concept, but the way it's written is completely different.
It is a ridiculous amount of ecchi, but that's ok, it's what they were going for, infact I actually started to laugh every time I saw the artists put jiggle motion emphasis on the breasts.
It has a decent sense of comedy, the story is well done in my opinion (No seriously, if you think it's a copy of hataraku maou-sama commit seppuku)
So generally I liked it, people will rate poorly because ithas some perverse scenes but it's not that bad, I enjoyed the series and I wish there were more episodes.

For some time now, I have maintained a strict no-dropping stuff policy and an always follow recommendations one, and I had never regretted that decision. Unfortunately, Yuusha ni Narenakatta Ore wa Shibushibu Shuushoku wo Ketsui Shimashita. made me hate myself for holding that ideal.
Yuusha ni Narenakatta Ore wa Shibushibu Shuushoku wo Ketsui Shimashita. (I Couldn't Become a Hero, So I Reluctantly Decided to Get a Job.) is an anime produced by Asread and directed by Kinji Yoshimoto (Genshiken 2, Machine-Doll wa Kizutsukanai). It is the adaptation of the light novel series of the same name.
While the premise may give hints of originality, the rest ofthe story does not present any whatsoever. Presenting almost no real story, the story focus on the day-to-day lives on the workers of the shop, which could have made an enjoyable slice-of-life, however, their lives fail to be compelling or even entertaining to watch, choosing to focus on ecchi. 


Don't get me wrong, I have no problems with ecchi if it doesn't become the main focus of a story. Hell, I enjoyed No Game No Life, and it was full of fanservice. Sadly, Yuushibu's is nothing more than a road between boob grabs and panty shots.


Towards the end of the season, Yuushibu tried hard to create a more dramatic and even political plot , but couldn't manage to do so. It tried to make an internal conflict for Fino (the Demon Lord's daughter), but its effort only resulted in laughably predictable storyline that, as always, resulted in breasts being exposed.


Incredibly, Fino was the most interesting character of the cast, with her quirky personality and lack of knowledge of the human world, even with her proness to nudity. The rest of the cast is hugely forgettable. Raul was a blank slate, with no real motivation for his desires. The other workers, all girls, with the exception of one guy, were only there for more panty shots and plot 


Said all that, it made a genuine effort to create an interesting world. Actually, it was the aspect of the anime I enjoyed the most (that is to say, the only aspect I enjoyed). It was lovely seeing how magic was integrated with day-to-day life. 


The comedy was unoriginal and missed the timing, most of the time. I can't remember laughing during any of the 12 episodes. It all felt too forced, with situations being created only to spawn jokes in a ridiculously obvious way.


The art was pretty looking, but, looking at it with more care, it failed  to create its own style, particularly with the character design, which looked like rehashes of stuff that we see numerous times through the years. The animation of the few battle scenes was quite smooth, specially considering Yuushibu is, for the most part, a slice-of-life.


Much like the visuals, the soundtrack was decent, but not above-average in any way. The same can be said about the voice acting.


I, personally, hated almost every second of it. I am normally an easy laugher, but I didn't find any of the comedy even remotely funny; the story was uninteresting; the character development was basically non-existent, and I was not into the fanservice.


I watchedYuushibu only because someone recommended it to me as a great slice-of-life with just one tiny bit of fanservice. I can't remember who did it, but I am never trusting that person again if I find him/her.


I would recommend it only for people looking for boobs and panties, as they will find a lot to enjoy. But I can't really recommend it to anyone else.


Feel free to leave your (constructive) criticsm in my profile!

I Couldn’t Become a Hero, So I Reluctantly Decided to Get a Job.
Yep, that’s the English name for the bullet train sized Japanese name of the anime I’m reviewing right now right up there in the blog post title. Geez, what a mouthful.
After waiting two whole years to hear some news on whether ‘The Devil Is A Part-Timer’ (highly recommended) would get a second season or not, I finally went crazy and decided to go on a hunt for similar anime. Luckily, it was pretty much just 5 second Google search and around 10 seconds of me reading the synopsis on MyAnimeList about this anime,which I’ll call ‘Yuu-ni’, to come to the conclusion that I had hit the jackpot and would thoroughly enjoy the next 4 hours or so.


The very first thing I have to say about Yuu-ni is… TITS. Like, no. I mean, yes! Tits. Fully exposed jiggly wiggly bosoms dancing around on your screen hilariously 3 minutes into the first episode of this anime. I did not expect this to be an ecchi show. Well, not THAT ecchi. The Devil Is A Part-Timer had plenty of ecchi. But, most of it was rather contained and there weren’t any fully bare breasts shaking up a fleshy storm almost every 4 minutes. So, be warned that if you can’t stand fanservice then it’s best that you just stop reading right here.


Now let’s get to actual meat of this review!


Raul is a strong and uptight cherry-boy that couldn’t become a Hero because the Demon Lord had his ass handed to him right before Raul’s Hero qualification examination. The Demon Lord-less world meant that there was no need for Heroes anymore and so, many current and aspiring Heroes and the industries involved with this work, like armories and weapon blacksmiths, were devastated and had to look for another source of income. And that’s why Raul is stuck reluctanly working in a magic shop. That is, until one day the Demon Lord’s daughter takes up a job at Raul’s shop and he’s stuck showing her the ropes while his life, his dreams, and his way of working are all turned upside down with each passing day bringing them closer.


And that’s the plot. Well, that’s the plot until the last 3 episodes where a major twist messes things up and actual non-ecchi action (relatively speaking here) takes center stage. Up until the twist, Yuu-ni was probably a 5/10 in my view. When the show ended, the rating went up to an 8 in terms of enjoyment and a 7 when considering the show objectively.


Since Yuu-ni isn’t a show I’ll ever recommend to anyone, I will discuss the twist and the ending and urge you to watch it if you’re looking for a fun ecchi show that knows what it is, takes pride in itself, and does not half-ass the things it wants to do.


The twist is that Fino, the Demon Lord’s daughter, is forced by some shady demon guy and a couple of Heroes to become the next Demon Lord. Fino ain’t want none o’ that shit. She justs want to be a normal salesperson and open up a magic shop in the demon world. So, a bunch of betrayals, fight scenes two or three levels below that of Fate’s, and a load of wittiness later: Raul saves the day.


It’s a pretty hectic end that ties up the starightforward story quite well. So where does the 6/10 from before the last few episodes come from? That would be the world-building, characters and the dry dramatic scenes. Let’s talk about Yuu-ni’s world first.


Is it a game world? The characters talk about being drained of HP and use game terms so, is it? Are the human world and the demon world different dimensions or in the same one? There’s a mountain that can either take you to or is the Demon Lord’s lair in the human world so, what gives?  Why didn’t the Heroes try to jobs as cops or join the military? Surely, there’s crime and humans are morons so there must be conflict amongst humans as well so, why? SO MANY QUESTIONS. NO ANSWERS. At least the jokes are funny. Somewhat.


The dramatic scenes can get too dramatic. Like crying for a very ‘why are the hell are you even crying?’ reason is something I despise. Especially in comedies. Over-passionate speeches and edgy monologues are things I let slide in non-comedies but here it’s a big ‘NO!’ from my side.


As in most comedies, it’s a one-dimensional harem paradise ensemble of cute ladies and two guys. Add in three more guys by the ending because who else is better suited to play the villain to cuties than two frustrated men and a thousand years less inexperienced Orihara Izaya? Raul gets some development over the course of the show. Fino is jolly smiles and doesn’t know the meaning of ‘sexual restraint’ until that twist. Other than for the fanservice, the rest of the cast is forgettable – well except for Searas, the boss of Raul’s shop, who is a joy to watch especially in battle where she’s selling goods from her shop. Real neat-o!


The animation is the actual highlight of the show. I just wish it focussed more on the action scenes. It’s still wonderfully fluid and suffers from no drops on quality, though. But it sometimes be too bright for me.


The sound… nothing special. Forgettable.


Overall, the score is a 5 out of 10. It was fun.

Shall we take a trip down the memory lane? The reason why I watch anime must have been started by watching Gundam Seed back in 2004, which I realized that anime is not just something similar to Scooby-Doo or Spongebob, but anime tells a story, unlike cartoons.
Why I watch anime since 2004 is not for the art, the OSTs, the mainstream-ness, the fanservice [okay I get there are those who get turned-on by 2D girls but still, reality-check], well, think of whatever positive notion or in worse cases, "stigma" of anime has, but I watch anime for the plot and characters.
I always just shrug thosekind of anime which just centers on visual entertainment, I even drop mainstream anime because 10% of their story is for the plot, 90% of it are fillers which have mostly nothing to do with what the story is all about. Most especially, and as much, I always cut ecchi anime off my system [dropped "To Love Ru" and its cousins], but Yuusha ni Narenakatta~~ or simply "Yuushibu" here, I gave it a go after a brother [great friend] of mine watched it, who also likes Hataraku Maou-sama [and other wicked anime like SnK, Madoka, Kyousougiga, etc etc].


At first I watched Yuushibu because of its similarities to Hataraku, but I could go on to say that Yuushibu was able to go on par with Hataraku even without borrowing elements from the ecchi realm.



STORY = 8

Over and over have we came across demons and heroes, and again, similar to Hataraku's development where the main character lost somewhat his purpose, the similarity of Yuushibu against Hataraku ends here. The significance of Yuushibu sets it apart.



ART = 7

I always don't get this "art" section, they animate, right? They should be good as that.



SOUND = 7

haven't checked much on the seiyuu's, but they're a great cast, especially Azusa Tadokoro voicing the adorable Fino.



CHARACTER = 10

Yes, my favorite thing to point-out in MAL, the character section.

So again, why am I watching anime, is because of the revolting story and characters.

Kiddies and anime-fans and otakus who just watch anime because the bishie is there, or there's fanservice and pantsu showing, simply just watches anime because of those kind of secondary-factors.

Primary factors always involve the plot and the character. That's the deep reason, man. You don't watch anime because you've seen pantsus, or because there's a cute bishoujo with big boobs on it.


What's with the plot? It's something about demons and heroes and a world almost the same as ours but with magic and the age of heroes ended.


What's with the character, then?

The good thing about the characterization of Yuushibu is simply not "rip-offs" of other ecchi anime. 

The main characters are dynamic, they have their conflicts from ep.1, and in the end of ep.12 [never mind the OVA, that's already the denouement] they were able to resolve it. What's good is it ties, or stitches with the plot. Yuushibu could stand alone with as it is "character-drivern" rather than plot-driven type of anime. How the characters resolved their conflicts in the end, that's as good as it gets. What's more, even if the story sets about demons and a fantasy-world, but their problems are "contemporary"---meaning we, people in this real-world, have the same kind of problems/ordeals they are having [job-related, lost, and other ordeals of their  that will flag the spoiler so I can't narrate it more here].

TBH, Yuushibu doesn't need to borrow ecchi-elements to stand-out; but because of the "Hataraku Maou-sama", then maybe they need the edge of ecchi to propel the series to recognition.



ENJOYMENT = 9

one of the very few ecchi [and at this point in time, I'll disregard this anime being ecchi, I don't have time for pantsu-ness and boobs-ness] anime that I enjoyed and didn't regret watching. This anime is totally worth the watch.



OVERALL = 8

Again, like I said in my review of Stella Jogakuin, anime-fans and otaku are very hard to please.

So this one here, being "randomly labeled" as ecchi just because of the eye-candy and some skin showing, doesn't mean it can simply be shoved alongside with the rest of the ecchi-genre. Yuushibu may not be one of a kind, but the fact that it made much importance of the aspects of the characters revolving in a world of demon-realm and fantasy, then Yuushibu may just be the only [ecchi] anime to do just that.

Well the story is quite normal fantasy-based but with its own twist. At least I haven't seen any other anime where the hero and the daughter of deceased demon lord work together in a magical general store.
Art-style is pleasing and I didn't find any half-assed scenes.
Sound quality is nice. Nothing outstanding but nothing bad either.
Small spoiler ahead!!
Characters have some stereotypes included for example the shop manager is by nature exactly the same as in Ika musume (nice all the time but when triggered powerful enough to destroy any foe). The character development is also there which is always a plus.
Enjoyment suffers from too many bouncing/nudeboobs-scenes which kinda annoys the viewer. Personally I like boobs but too much is just too much and it starts to get repetitive and annoying.\n\n
Overall the show is a good refresher after watching a much more darker and action-packed show.

This.... this was just bad. 
Bland, unimaginative, with uninspired characters.... imagine if someone took "Wagnaria" or "Hataraki Maou-sama" and took all the humor and life out of it. It is a very depressing anime about how some people gave up on their dreams, failed to find their place in life, landed at odd job in retail stores, and then spent 12 episodes convincing themselves that this is how the things should be. Well, at least that's the way this anime feels. It is SUPPOSED to be a comedy about ex-hero and Daughter of ex-maou (i.e. "demon lord") working together in a retail store. However, itis not very fun, characters are bland, the world is not very interesting, there's some very awkwardly done and disruptive attempts of fan-service (the anime really loves boobs, but has no clue how to properly include them into the story), and pretty much the only ray of hope in this depressing mess is main heroine - Fino. However, her positive qualities are not strong enough to make watching this anime a positive experience.


Story:

Very bland, unconvincing, and fairly unimaginative. There were heroes that were training to defeat "the demon lord", but someone killed the demon lord first, so they end up working inr etail stores. The world does not really look like fantasy, and resembles modern day settings, with few minor modifications in it (magic being electricity, and cars being driven by monsters). There were downright cringeworthy moments involving interactions with other stores, plus, as I said, anime handles fanservice very awkwardly. The anime never loses an opportunity to focus on someone's breasts, butt or show a panty-shot, however, this looks out of place and does not fit the anime well.


Art:

The main heroine - Fino, resembles a character from Denpa onna to Seishun no Otoko. It almost looks like she is much more detailed that pretty much anyone else in the series and that her image is of higher quality. All the other characters are fairly low detailed, and backgrounds usually are nothing interesting. The anime uses some very obvious cg for some background objects, thankfully it is not used for characters, otherwise it would've been truly horrible. Basically, Fino is drawn well, but everything else - not so well.


Sound:

Doesn't really stand out, and there's nothing to say. I liked how  Fino was voiced, though.


Characters:

Bad. All of them. Well, all of them except Fino. Fino looks fairly convincing - and works well as a naive daughter of demon lord who never knew manners of the human world (which also explains fairly well her lack of shame regarding being nude on more than one occasion). She's occasionally charming and even cute. Her visual design is fairly interesting too. However, everybody else acts in strange awkward fashion on every occasion, and their characters are unconvincing. I can't recall any trait that could describe any character aside from their looks or uniforms. Few characters obsess over their past of "would be heroes", but that's about it.


Enjoyment:

IT was one of the worse animes I watched. Fino by herself was interesting, and I liked her character, but the world and the rest of the cast was so badly done, that Fino had no chance of saving the show. 


Overall:

I'd say skip it. It is not a good harem anime, not a good fanservice anime, not a good comedy, not a good adventure, overall it is quite bad. Fino is an interesting, cute and likeable character, but the rest of the show is quite awful, so Fino alone doesn't really justify watching this show. You might as well look up Fino's designs online, or search for screenshots of the movie.


So, the best idea is to skip it, unless you're really bored, or really like fino, or literally have nothing else to watch. On other hand... I saw worse animes than this.

-TL;DR REVIEWS-
Tl;dr - This anime sucks. Don't bother watching it. Watch "Hataraku" instead.
[STORY - 6] - The protagonist is a hero who has reluctantly become a simple cashier at Reon's due to the lack of necessity for heroes which stems from the defeat of the demon lord. 
Surprisingly~, the demon lord's heir soon joins the Reon's team and must adapt to generic human life.
Rising action and the 'serious' tone begins at episode 8. 
I would give the story a 7 but I got extremely bored past episode 8 and had to deduct a point.
[ART - 8] - Great animation, especially for being made in 2013.


There's lots of fanservice, if you're into it. 


I personally did not add nor deduct points for the fanservice, because its irrelevant to the score of 8 in terms of great animation.


[CHARACTERS - 5] Nothing special.


Main character is the typical 'clueless to romance' archetype prevalent in many anime. The side characters are nothing special, and just used as a means of fanserivce/ecchi.


[ENJOYMENT - 5] - I enjoyed it at the beginning but the anime slowly became shittier/boring. It was a chore to finish the series. 


[OVERALL - 5] - I'd honestly say to skip this anime and save yourself the time.


If you want a fantasy 'fall-from-grace' romantic comedy, I'd recommend "Hataraku".

Yūsha ni Narenakatta Ore wa Shibushibu Shūshoku o Ketsui Shimashita, or I Couldn’t Become a Hero, So I Reluctantly Decided to Get a Job, or commonly shortened to Yu-Sibu is another Fall 2013 comedy anime. 
Now, Yu-Sibu is all about a protagonist named Raul Chaser (Or, Rauru Cheisa, if you’re a direct translation kinda fan) who grew up wanting to be a hero and kill the Demon Lord. When our anime begins he is in the final days of his Hero Training, and is one of the best in his class, but when someone else kills the Demon Lord, all of the Heroes, adventure supplystores, and Heroes-in-training lose their jobs. Now plunged into the regular world with little-to-no job experience outside of demon fighting, Raul is forced to get a job at a magical appliance store called Leon’s. A while after Raul gets his job he meets the secondary character, Fino Bloodstone, the daughter of the Demon Lord that Raul had sworn to kill! Despite this pair having such an interesting dynamic, Yu-Sibu keeps up an “adventure of the day” sort of feel, with a few overarching plot lines such as keeping Leon’s in business. Or at least, it did until the final few episodes.


There are a decent number of important characters in this anime, including our dynamic duo of Raul and Fino, the other employees of Leon’s, as well as other friends from around town. However, due to the happy-go-lucky feel of this anime, the only other character that felt fully utilized was Airi Ortinet, Raul’s close friend and rival from his hero days. Airi begins looking down on Raul’s deciding to get a job, however once the two meet up again after the closing of the Hero program, they slowly start rebuilding their friendship and work ethic.


Yu-Sibu had some decent background music, with a few tracks really inspiring my sense of adventure. The ending didn’t really have anything of note but the opening, oh the opening… It was a cutesy song with a very funny video. Nothing that I’d put on my iPod, but nice all the same.


It did have a bit more fanservice than I’d like, but not too much more than average for an anime of this genre/feel. In the end I’m giving Yūsha ni Narenakatta Ore wa Shibushibu Shūshoku o Ketsui Shimashita an 8/10 because it did have some genuinely funny (albeit occasionally crude) scenes, and I could honestly relate to and feel for Raul throughout the series.


If you enjoyed this review, please check out my anime review blog at trips-anime-review.tumblr.com

This is one of those late bloomer type of anime, where the first half of the season is so so, then on the second half you'd be whining "Hurry up i need the next episode NOW!". The world in which the anime takes place is really nice and original, being mana powered and all. I don't actually like the art, but its pretty good because of everything else.

Ok, lets get this out of the way. There is 1 spoiler that I will say right now, and that is also the biggest disappointment in the anime, the cliche happens. Think of it, demon lords daughter comes to the human world, and the dad is, at least in this show, dead. From episode 1 I saw this coming, and was hoping I was wrong, and up till then, I thought I was. Up till the end of episode 8 I was thinking that maybe i was wrong and the cliche wasn't going to happen, but than it happened... than episode 9 came around, andI thought it could still go a different route... it doesn't.


With that said, when they pull the cliche, they do it in an interesting way revealing a little at a time that its not just the obvious white and black, but manage to do a shade of grey approach.


Now, episode 1-9 (before the ending) feel like I'm watching episodes of working but in a different setting, and with a story backbone, and if it was just those 9 episodes, I would rate this a 10... but the cliche does it in for me and made it much less enjoyable because I knew how  the last 3 episodes were going to go, with the last episode I knew the direction almost point by point. These episodes also feel so VERY rushed, where they just bomb the thing with plot that shows up like we should already know what is going on, which if you read the source material, you may very well get a better appreciation for it, but as I cant read japanese, and am fairly sure nothing substantial is in english, I cant confirm. 


TL:DR

If you know what the cliche is just by me saying that, you may also not enjoy the last few episodes, or at the very least say they are the weakest part of the show. If you don't know what the cliche is by me saying cliche... than this very well could be a 10 out of 10 anime for you.

2nd review here so please be gentle. 
Yuusha Ni Narenakat- Oh for the gods' sakes... What is with Japanese and in long anime title names????
Unlike other reviews, I'm not gonna go over the characters and summary of the story because it's in the synopsis. Besides, I'm too lazy to type that out. Thanks Review Guidelines-san. 
Anyways, let's see first the story.
Story: 3
Oh where to begin. Let's see. An interesting backdrop story featuring a guy trying to be a hero, but failed to do so due to sudden changing circumstances that is beyond his control? Check.  And thus having to settle for the lowest optionavailable as a store clerk? Check. He works with many busty and/or sexually appealing girls (and one dude...)? Check. A new girl arrives in town? Check. Boy meets girl? Check. The main character is a cherry boy (virgin)? Check. And he clearly acts like one? Double check. 

This is one of your stereotypical harem animes where it features a very boring and bland main character that was "supposedly" designed to represents the majority of the male audiences... Like every other boring and average MCs in existence... Oh wait. Forgot to mention, they are supposed to represent the majority of JAPANESE males. And it really shows in not only their manner and upbringing, but in their flaws, too. In both the characters and writing intended for the said demographics. This is one of those guilty pleasure animes that is not supposed to be taken seriously, like the anime adaptation of High school of the Dead. But even that anime has more story and things going on than this one that I'm reviewing. The story was more or less a promising adventure medieval fantasy backdrop at the beginning, but then it quickly turned into a more modernized setting where the guy works at a retail store. A store that supposedly existed in a medieval fantasy realm.... Reason? Japanese storytelling convenience. They don't even explain how they gotten to that point of civilization either. It was just there... FOR YEARS. So it just goes on as much slice of life and glorifying Japanese culture aka the work/retail culture and industry. Like any other Working (no pun intended) or job or career animes. But again with that medieval fantasy twist. But it serves no other function other than being able to touch the medieval fantasy fetish side in people and offer a demon lord's daughter as part of the *main moe fetish dish". And it doesn't ever get serious until near the end, but even that was pointless since it was more like trying to advance the overarching story, even when there was barely any development on it, therefore made the rising development almost completely out of left field. 

So you ask me for the story rating?  Honestly I don't watch a whole lot of animes, but I can definitely this was one of the worst one so far. Don't come here looking for a story. It's just a fanservice anime through and through. One that sometimes flits around in trying to take itself seriously, while mostly not....



Art: 6

I don't see a whole lot of animes much lately so I can't properly rate it like one of those high end critics or even reviewers here who have tons of anime under their belt. But I can definitely say it was pretty solid, especially due to the fact that they don't rely on CG. Especially during the fight scenes. Instead they use more of the traditional cell shade animations. But that unforutanetly tends to show during fight scenes where the colors look off or bland due to the time constraints and demanding poses and scenes. But it was still solid. It was not Konosuba S2E1 launch bad.... 

As for the characters art, some of them looked very early 2k anime style coloring and lines, but it was not that bad. The stockings on the girls looked fantastic, but due to such, it often heavily contrasted that it sometimes catches TOO well. Oh and please don't look at their toes (swimsuit ep)....

As for the fanservice aka the boobs. .....Unable to compute. Only found Phino's completely bare chests shown MANY times throughout the entire season. Airi only reveals the nipples on her pantyhose suit, otherwise the nipples are never to be seen. Only the general shape of her breasts. As for the other girls, they sadly don't get that much level of fanservice. AT ALL. Few are even exempt such as Lore. So if you were hoping for breast and nudity and fan-service diversity, the likes of which you could see in High School DxD? Sorry. You're all fresh out of luck on that one. You gonna have to settle for the main heroine, whether you like it or not. 



Sound: 4

What can I say? It was pretty much stereotypical upbeat harem ecchi anime? Thus the music fitted to it as such esp in the OP and ED theme. Worse is when it gets all serious, but then the upbeat song comes into play.....



Character: 3

Oh gods... Where to start on this one. Like any other harems, the MC is as exciting as a flattened nail on a 2x4... He may be a powerful hero candidate, but that's all his redeeming features. He has no other skills. He has nothing to offer other than being the "straight man" in many wacky situations. He may be diligent worker. But that's all he is. If you are looking for a useful character that can kick butt? Sorry, not until near the end of the season, and it's highly debatable if he's even useful or redeemable during or even after the fact. 

Then for the main heroine.... Well she's one of those cheery happy-go-lucky main heroines? Welcome back to the 90s tropes. She's your titular go to character for any character development and fap material.... Because that's all she is. A bundle of fanservice served on a silver platter. She's almost the only one to let it all show. And the only one you will almost ever see. The other girls? They are all chopped liver, in terms of story, development, plot (of both kinds), and so on and so on. Them being potential love interests? Pft. Fat chance. This is one of those animes where it clearly pushes for the main ship MCxMH by beating it into your head with a stick. There's no room for anyone else. And with poor screentime and development for them, you almost won't care. Though I really cared about Airi. She had some potential here.... But another terrible that wastes away good potential characters in its own narrowsighted goal. And that goal is to promote and perpetuate the MH as the absolute perfect goddess and go-to waifu that she supposedly is. Everyone else is just a mere afterthought or slight intrigue, nothing more. 


Enjoyment: 3

This was not enjoyable at all. Other than the awesome old man getting his kicks off of Nova or Airi displaying her own unique brand of fanservice in the beginning and near the end, there was nothing much to stay around for. The MC was utterly boring, the MH tends to grate on my nerves due to her constant trouble making, courtesy of her dubious upbringing and personality. And there's the fact that many of the *fights* are treated like a joke. Like the girls other than Phino, the fights were also a "afterthought" or probably made it with whatever left over budget they could squeeze for *fight scenes*. So if you were looking for DxD or any other fighting/adventure anime level of fights, nope. It left much to be desired. Especially not only how short and sudden they were but also because of strong and OP the MC and manager was... Seriously... Why was there even a fight with these strong entities?? It was almost completely one-sided. 


Overall: 4

I did NOT enjoy the story or the whole progression. If it wanted to be a career slice of life anime? Then fine. Be one. If it wanted to be an adventure thriller anime like DxD or any other medieval fantasy animes (whether it has actual old medieval elements or modern elements), then also fine. Be one. But don't try to be both if you can't even execute it properly. It all fell flat in how it all integrated with each other since they don't explain how it all integrated with each other. Like it just... "was". No need to explain. Too complicated. Focus on story. Oh wait no story? Sorry forgot. Just focus on the tits please. 


Personally for me, the only girl and waifu to take from all of this was Airi because she was almost the only sane girl in the entire group that wasn't a complete space case (Nova, the next door cashier), a cloud nine-walker (the manager), or loudspeakers (Ram, Phione). Although there was Lore who was the series' resident kuudere. But she gets very little screen-time other than to advance the story and plot. Otherwise she might as well not have existed. Because she didn't put on the bathing suit for the appropriate ep. She doesn't even strip at all or provide fanservice. She only gets naked for a bathhouse scene, and she still shows very little.... So honestly, the true takeaway from me that was a MH all shoved right into my face, was Airi, who honestly should've been the true MH due to how they made the ED credit animation and how she the first girl to show up when the show started. But alas, she gets pushed to the side for the "new girl in town".... So it was all a waste of time other than be able to rescue a poor character that was doomed to be neglected and adopt her and make her one of my waifus (Airi).


If you like that sort of thing or don't care for the "articles" (in other words you're here for the "plot"), then this anime is for you. Enjoy.


But if you are like me and have actual standards? Avoid this. Other than maybe seeing it for best girl Airi (completely subjective opinion)...
